title: A Taste of Time: The Culinary Showdown
storyText:
A Taste of Time: The Culinary Showdown

## A Taste of Time: The Culinary Showdown **Description:** This story follows the contestants on a unique cooking show where they must recreate dishes from different historical periods.

It’s a fun way to learn and practice various English tenses.

**Level:** Intermediate --- **Section 1: The Announcement & The Victorian Challenge** The studio *buzzed* with excitement.

"Welcome to 'A Taste of Time.

'” announced the host, Chef Remy Dubois, with a flourish.

“This show *will test* your culinary skills and your historical knowledge.

Each week, our contestants *will face* a new era, and *must recreate* a signature dish.

" Among the contestants *stood* young Maya, a pastry chef, and seasoned chef, Antonio.

The first round.

Victorian England.

"You *have* 60 minutes to impress me with a truly authentic Victorian dish.

” Chef Remy declared.

**Verb Check (circle the correct tense):** 1.

buzzed / buzzes / will buzz 2.

will test / tests / tested 3.

will face / face / faced 4.

stood / stand / is standing 5.

have / has / had --- **Section 2: Research & Recipies** Maya *had already researched* Victorian cuisine extensively.

“Oh dear,” she *muttered* to herself, flipping through a faded cookbook.

"They *used* a lot of rich sauces and heavy spices.

I *wondered* if I could simplify it without losing the authentic flavour.

" Antonio, meanwhile, *was looking* through a digital archive, stating, “My grandmother *made* incredible Yorkshire pudding.

I *believe* I can tackle this challenge.

" He *hadn't anticipated* the complexity of sugar sculpting, though.

**Verb Check:** 1.

had researched / researched / will research 2.

muttered / mutters / is muttering 3.

used / use / using 4.

wondered / wonders / will wonder 5.

was looking / looks / looked --- **Section 3: The Heat of the Kitchen** The kitchen *was a whirlwind* of activity.

Maya *was carefully assembling* a trifle, layering sponge cake with custard and fruit.

She *realized* she *had forgotten* to pre-soak the fruit - a critical mistake.

Antonio, on the other hand, *struggled* with the intricate sugar decorations for his gingerbread castles.

“I *have almost finished*,” he grunted, wiping sweat from his brow.

Chef Remy *walked* by, observing the chaos.

**Verb Check:** 1.

was / is / were 2.

was assembling / assembles / assembled 3.

realized / realise / realising 4.

had forgotten / forgotten / will forget 5.

have almost finished / almost finished / finished --- **Section 4: Presentation & Judging** Time *was up*.

Maya *presented* her trifle, explaining, "I *tried* to recreate the traditional Victorian flavour profile, though I *made* a slight adjustment to the sugar levels.

" Antonio, despite his sugar struggles, *showed* a majestic, although slightly wonky, gingerbread castle.

Chef Remy *tasted* each dish carefully.

“Maya," he began, "your trifle *has been* delightful, a true reflection of the period.

” He then turned to Antonio.

"Antonio, you *pushed* yourself, but the presentation *could have been* better.

” **Verb Check:** 1.

was / is / were 2.

presented / presents / is presenting 3.

tried / try / trying 4.

made / make / is making 5.

has been / is / was --- **Section 5: The Reveal & Future Challenges** “And the winner of the Victorian challenge is… Maya.

” Chef Remy announced.

Maya *beamed*.

"I *am so excited*.

" she exclaimed.

“Next week,” Chef Remy continued, “we *will travel* to Ancient Rome.

You contestants *will recreate* a feast fit for an Emperor.

By the time the show *has finished*, you *will have learned* about culinary history from across the centuries.

” Antonio, though disappointed, *promised* to come back stronger.

**Verb Check:** 1.

beamed / beam / is beaming 2.

am / is / are 3.

will travel / travel / travelled 4.

will recreate / recreate / recreated 5.

has finished / finished / is finishing.
